abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the National Agricultural Research Project
            in Kenya. The main objectives were to: (i) focus on priority
            research programs with a significant likelihood of high and
            early returns to investment; (ii) develop technologies hat
            contribute to increased productivity, particularly of
            smallholdings; (iii) intensify producer participation in
            research program formulation; and (iv) strengthen linkages
            between research and other agricultural services such as
            extension, as well as between the new agricultural research
            establishment and other institutions involved in
            agricultural research. Bank and borrower's performance
            were satisfactory. The main lessons learned from
            implementation include: (a) While it is important to
            identify up-front the longer-term national Program
            objectives, it is also necessary to design and manage the
            time-slice interventions as phased process projects, with
            specific immediate objectives (as subsets of the program
            goals), achievable over a shorter initial time horizon; (b)
            In a country as diverse as Kenya, prioritization of
            commodities and factors of production is useful if
            undertaken within a broad agro-climatic framework and after
            prioritization of therelative importance of each major
            production zone; (c) A farming system approach is useful
            (perhaps essential) in promoting research/extension liaison
            and ensuring relevance in research, where there is high
            variability in resource base and population pressure; (d)
            Staff rationalization and retrenchment is extremely
            difficult in countries where public sector employment is
            used as a means of social security. (e) A clear memorandum
            of understanding between the agencies responsible for
            research and extension, with arrangements for provision of
            funds by the recipient extension agency directly to the
            Regional Research Centres' (RRCs) for joint activities,
            can lead to good cooperation and a successful outcome; and
            (f) Multi-donor projects need strong coordination from one
            source within the Government.

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Agricultural Research
            Project supported by several donors comprises assistance
            for: (i) restructuring of the Kenya Agricultural Research
            Institute (KARI) organization and management, including
            establishment costs, construction of a headquarters
            building, training and external expert assistance for
            research planning and management, budgeting and information
            systems; (ii) rehabilitation and provision of equipment and
            operating funds to Regional Research Centers and (iii)
            support to key national crop, livestock, factor and
            disciplinary research programs.  IDA seeks to provide
            funding for incremental non-salary operating costs,
            vehicles, equipment, civil works, the research information
            and reporting system, and some training and consultancy
            services. Effective donor coordination is an essential
            element of the project.
